profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T19:29-0400

did.abstract: This collection includes correspondence on natural history and evolution, and especially on his collection and study of shells from Japan and the Pacific islands. Principal correspondents include Louis Agassiz, Charles Robert Darwin, Sir William Henry Flower, Alpheus Hyatt, George Newbold Lawrence, George J. Romanes, Alfred R. Wallace, and the Linnean Society of London.
did.physloc: LH-MV-C-10 (B G96, B G96.h, B G96.r); LH-MV-E-2 (B G96r.1)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gulick, Addison. See in-house shelf list for additional dates and numbers.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Many of the letters were printed in Addison Gulick, "Evolutionist and Missionary: John Thomas Gulick, Portrayed Through Documents and Discussions" (Chicago, 1932).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Thomas Gulick (1832-1923) was born at Waimea, Kauai, Hawaii. The son of Rev. Peter Johnson and Fanny Hinckley (Thomas) Gulick, early American missionaries to Hawaii, he travelled extensively as a missionary and contributed to the early development of evolutionary science, beginning with his study of Hawaiian land snails.

Gulick studied at Punahou Academy in Honolulu and the preparatory department of the University of the City of New York. After a short time in California, where he worked as a miner (1849-1850) he graduated from Williams College in 1859 and the Union Theological Seminary in 1861. In 1862 he travelled to Japan, supporting himself by teaching and photography which trying to convince the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions to begin work in the area. From 1864 to 1899 he worked as a Board missionary in various locations, including Peking and Kalgan in China and Kobe and Osaka in Japan. Returning to the United States in 1900, he studied problems related to evolution at Oberlin, Ohio.

Gulick maintained that perfect harmony is possible between science and religion, and that the two major themes of his life – missionary work and evolutionary biology – were perfectly compatible. His son and biographer notes: “The scientist’s psychology would be but half told without the portrayal of the almost mystical religious awe with which great scientific truths were approached. And the development … of a carefully thought philosophy of life would be unaccounted for without an exposition of the scientific concepts that gave an impetus to changing stand-points toward religion and the problems of human conduct. To a singular degree the diversity of Gulick’s achievements sprang out of a unity of personal character and purpose.”

Gulick was twice married. His first wife, Emily de la Cour, died in 1874. With his second wife, Frances A. Stevens, he had two children, Addison and Louise. In 1906 Gulick returned to Hawaii to devote himself to the study of social problems. He died there in 1923, at the age of ninety-one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in this collection represent primarily one facet of Gulick’s life, that of evolutionary theorist and natural philosopher. The correspondence deal with his collection of shells collected in Hawaii, publications on evolution, and his running debate with Alfred Russel Wallace.

The correspondence are separated into three series. Series one is general correspondence, and represents a cross-section of all of the above themes. Series two is composed of nineteen letters between Gulick and the prominent American zoologist and paleontologist Alpheus Hyatt (1838-1902). The letters are primarily concerned with natural history in general, and specifically with details of Gulicks collections of Hawaiian shells and publications related to them. Series three is composed of 60 letters, the majority of which are between Gulick and the English evolutionary theorist George John Romanes (1848-1894), and refer mostly to evolutionary debate between Gulick and Alfred Russel Wallace, publications on evolution and Gulick’s collection of Hawaiian shells.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in series one is the most varied, and deal with Gulick’s efforts to find a home for his collection of shells and his publications and presentations with the Linnean Society. Of particular interest are three letters with Charles Darwin, the original of which are in the Darwin papers (B D25).
D. 19 items. Various sizes. Presented by Addison Gulick; July 1960.

did.unittitle: The distribution of plants and animals;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.D. 11p.,end. (see J.T. Gulick. Correspondence; 1853-1888.) "Read before the Punahou Debating Society April 7, 1853" Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary, J.T.Gulick,pp.114-119.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. (see J.T.Gullick. Correspondence...: 1853-1888.) Asks for map to accompany his paper, with Wallace will present for publication to the Linnean Society. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary, p.235.

did.unittitle: Letter to J[ohn] T. Gulick, New York;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cambridge, A.L.S. 1p. (see J.T. Gulick. Correpondence...; 1853-1888.) Concerning geographic distribution and the Darwinian theory. Printed: A. Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary, p.237.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence...; 1853-1888.) Asks to meet him and discuss the distribution of species of Hawaiian mollusks. Printed: A.Gulick.Evolutionist and Missionary,J.T.Gulick. pp.233.

scopecontent.p: London, A.L.S.: W. Percy Sladen. 2p.and end.and receipt for £15.0.0 (see Gulick papers.) Concerning his paper on divergent evolution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: London, L.S. 3p.and add.,end. (see Gulick papers.) Must decline the purchase of his shells

did.unittitle: Letter to Prof. [Sir William Henry] Flower;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 12p. Draft of letter, in pencil (see Gulick papers.) Concerning the final disposition of his shell collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 2p. Draft, in pencil. (see J.T. Gulick. Correspondence...; 1853-1888.) Forwards paper on evolution and asks for comments on it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. (see Gulick papers.) Can see him next Friday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cambridge, A.L.S. 2p. (see Gulick papers.) Thanks him for his paper and believes his solution correct.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York, A.L.S. 3p. (see Gulick papers) Asks what to do with the birds left with him. Some were presented to the American museum of natural history. On same sheet is: Gulick to Lawrence; June 14, 1889.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Medina, A.L. 2p. Draft. (see Gulick papers.) His brother presents birds to American museum of natural history. Hopes it will purchase his collection of shells. On same sheet as: Lawrence to Gulick; Oct. 5,1888.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York, A.L.S. 2p. (see Gulick papers.) Thanks for the birds for the American museum of natural history. Inquires of his collection of shells.

did.unittitle: Suggestions concerning the mounting of the geographical collection of land shells from the Island of Oahu;

did.unittitle: Series Two: Correspondence with Alpheus Hyatt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Gulick and the prominent American zoologist and paleontologist Alpheus Hyatt (1838-1902), primarily concerned with natural history in general, and specifically with details of Gulicks collections of Hawaiian shells and publications related to them.
D. 19 items. Various sizes. Presented by Addison Gulick; July 1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, Typed L.S. 4p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Hyatt.) Recommends he publish a major work on Hawaiian mollusks. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary...; pp.321-322.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston Typed L.S. 5p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Hyatt.) Believes the Boston society of natural history would purchase his collection of shells, but wants a definite statement of the sale price.

scopecontent.p: Boston, Typed L. 1p.and add.,end. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Hyatt) Inquires for cost of his collection of shells.

did.unittitle: Series Three: Correspondence with George John Romanes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Gulick and the English evolutionary theorist George John Romanes (1848-1894), refering mostly to evolutionary debate between Gulick and Alfred Russel Wallace, publications on evolution and Gulick’s collection of Hawaiian shells.
Also included in this series is a bound volume containing transcripts of the correspondence between Gulick and Romanes.
D. 60 items. Various sizes. Presented by Addison Gulick; June 1960. Table of contents available.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with George John Romanes, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typescript. 1 vol.bound of 195p. Printed (in large part): Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary. Originals in: B:G96.r. Presented by Addison Gulick; Jan. 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Concerning his paper which Wallace is forwarding to the Linnean society for possible publication. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionst and missionary...; pp.404-405.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Recommended to the Linnean Society that his paper on evolution be published. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary...; pp.405-406.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rome, A.L. 4p. Draft. In pencil. (see Gulick papers.) Concerning the publication of his article: "Divergent Evolution through Cumulative Segregation". Refers to Wallace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Genoa, A.L.S. 4p. Draft. (see Gulick papers.) Printed in part: Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary; p.406.

did.unittitle: Letter to J[ohn] T. Gulick, London;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S.on postal card. 1p.and add. (see J.T.Gulick Correspondence with Romanes.) Asks to borrow shells from Hawaii.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. (see J.T. Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Suggests he send a copy of his paper on evolution to Henri de Varigny. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary...; 407-408.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 6p. Draft. (see Gulick papers.) Printed in part: Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary; pp.408-409.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Thanks for the loan of his shells. Hopes he can sell his collection in England. Printed in part: A.Gulick.Evolutionist and missionary...; 409-410

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Makes suggestions for his reply to Wallace on evolution. Refers to Huxley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L. 8p. Draft. In pencil. (see Gulick papers.) Printed (almost completely): Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary; pp.410-411.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 3p. Draft. In pencil. (see Gulick papers.) Concerning shipment and responsibility of his shells. Encloses suggested receipt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T. Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Concerning the dispute with Wallace. Concerning his ideas on evolution. Shells. Printed: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary...; pp.411-412.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L. 17p. Draft. Partly in pencil. (see Gulick papers.) Printed (in large part): Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary; pp.412-415.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Concerning Wallace and natural selection. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionst and missionary...; pp.416-417.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 4p. (see J.T. Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Concerning natural selection. Concerning Wallace and Darwinism. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary...;p.417.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S.. 4p. (see J.T. Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes. Prefers no controversy with Wallace. Thinks that a book on evolution would be of much greater importane, based on his study of shells. Printed in part: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary...; p.417.

did.unittitle: Letter to J[ohn] T[homas] Gulick, Osaka;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 1p.and add.,end. Carbon copy. (see Gulick papers.) Delivered shells to Dr. Hyatt.

did.unittitle: Letter to John T. Gulick, Osaka;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 2p.and add.,end. (see Gulick papers.) Be some delay for payment for shells from Hyatt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Osaka, A.L.S. 3p. Draft. Partly in pencil. (see Gulick papers.) Sends reply to Wallace's criticism on segregation.

scopecontent.p: A.L. 4p. Draft. In pencil. (see Gulick papers.) Printed: Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary, pp.454-455.

did.unittitle: Letter to J[ohn T.] Gulick, Osaka, Japan;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oxford, Typed L.S. 1p.and add.,end. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Concerning his publication of Darwin and Darwinism. Printed in part; A. Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary.. pp.455-456.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Osaka, A.L.S. 1p. Draft. (see Gulick papers.) Sorry he is ill. Grants permission to publish letter on insects.

did.unittitle: Letter to J[ohn T.] Gulick, Osaka, Japan;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oxford, A.L.S.on postal card. 1p.and add. (see J.T.Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Asks for negative for photograph of self for purposes of reproducing it.

did.unittitle: Letter to John [T.] Gulick, Osaka, Japan;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S.on postal card. 1p.and add. (see J.T. Gulick. Correspondence with Romanes.) Asks for autograph for purpose of reporducing it. Printed: A.Gulick. Evolutionist and missionary...; p.309.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. Draft. 2p.of signatures of "John T. Gulick" (see Gulick papers.) Printed in part: Gulick. Evolutionist and Missionary; p.310.

did.unittitle: Address Sheet to John T. Gulick

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Envelope addressed to Gulick with stamps. Pencil note: "These were sent to Mrs. Romanes through the publishers of her life of Romanes..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 2p. Draft. (see Gulick papers.) Introduces a young student of natural history who is capable of understanding the "Wider and truer philosophy of evolution which you are seeking to propagate."
